awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:    The Community-based Whole Magnetosphere Model (CWMM)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and validate a community-based whole magnetosphere model that simulates the interaction of the solar wind and interplanetary magnetic field with the near-Earth space environment. The model will extend from 100km above the Earth's surface to outside of the magnetospheric bow shock. The Community-based Whole Magnetosphere Model (CWMM) will model the magnetic and electric fields, neutral and plasma composition, pressure, and velocities, and energetic particle environment. Data assimilation will be used to make the model more consistent with the data. To achieve this goal, models of individual regions developed by various teams in the space sciences community will be used as components in the CWMM. The models will be coupled together using the Space Weather Modeling Framework (SWMF). The resulting coupled model will be made available to the space science and space weather communities through the Community Coordinated Modeling Center. A rigorous validation process will quantify how the accuracy of the model changes as more components are added. The project will move the coupled model toward operational status for use by the Air Force Weather Agency and  NOAA's Space Environment Center (SEC). Results from this project will also be used in the Space Weather curriculum that is being developed at the University of Michigan.  

This project is jointly funded by NASA and NSF.

por.por_cntn:
As part of the CWMM (Community-based Whole Magnetosphere Model) project, UC Berkeley provided several important analyses that supported the scientific goals of the project.

Auroral Morphology and Dynamics

Earth's magnetosphere redirects much of the energy in the solar wind toward the polar regions, driving electrical currents and energetic ions into the auroral zones. By studying the aurora, we try to understand how that process occurs. UC Berkeley has an extensive record of global auroral images from the NASA IMAGE mission, showing aurora produced by electrons and protons in separate images. Magnetospheric models that attempt to simulate the transport of energy and momentum from the solar wind to Earth must capture auroral currents and particles in a realistic manner, matching the location of the aurora, the way it changes with time, and the amount of energy it transfers to our atmosphere. UC Berkeley scientist helped improve the Whole Magnetospheric Model by comparing the aurora predicted by the magnetospheric model with the actual global scale images, providing analyses that helped U of Michigan scientists make a more realistic magnetospheric simulation.

Atmospheric Heating

In the upper atmosphere, heavier atoms and molecules (Like nitrogen molecules) sink to the bottom, while lighter atoms like hydrogen atoms rise to the top. This is very unlike the atmosphere we breathe, and when the auroral heats it, all the atoms can get mixed up until well after the aurora is over. As the aurora heats the upper atmosphere (above 60 miles/100 kilometer altitude), it both expands and mixes. This has interesting effects that combine to changes the density of both the neutral atmosphere and the ionosphere. From space, this can be seen with special cameras that "see" ultraviolet light. For this project, UC Berkeley scientists evaluated the amount of mixing the aurora created with global UV images from the same camera that took the auroral images noted above. The portion of the community magnetospheric model that captures the atmospheric heating of the aurora also simulates the mixing, and we compared this mixing to the actual images of mixing, finding differences and helping to improve the way the model simulates the absorption of solar wind energy into the atmosphere.

These two studies both factor into improving how we determine and predict changes in upper atmospheric density during geomagnetic storms, which directly changes the orbits of all satellites in low-Earth orbit (e.g. the International Space Station). Furthermore, the strong changes in atmospheric mixing can enhance sharp differences in plasma densities in near-Earth space that can interfere with GPS-based navigation and radio communications. Predicting these effects with better accuracy requires improvements to our understanding of how solar wind energy is coupled to our atmosphere through the magnetosphere, and our research combining sophisticated numerical models with cutting-edge space-based observations help us understand that process.

 

Thomas Immel

February 25, 2012
